speaker: {name:'Richard Palmer',webURLs:'[{url:'www.wspgroup.com',title:'WSP'},{url:'http://www.iol.co.za/dailynews/opinion/it-s-about-brave-decisions-1.1310907#.T9MM2uItg68',title:'Interview by Justin Nurse (LeadSA)'},{url:'http://thepointyend-of-sustainability.blogspot.com/2012/09/future-cities-africa-story.html',title:'Richard on future cities in his blog: the pointy end of sustainability'}]'}
description: Richard is an engineer by training, a consultant by profession and an ecologist at heart. In the real world he is employed by the WSP Group to offer design advice on green buildings and urban sustainability.
title: water:sewer:power:food

speaker: {name:'Joseph Wamicha',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.linkedin.com/pub/joseph-wamicha/2/478/848',title:'Joseph on LinkedIn'}]'}
description: Joseph has over 12 years experience in the Software Industry. He specialises in open source software running on Linux and all flavours of UNIX, using languages such as C, PHP, Python and JAVA. Joseph's passion is to empower all of Africa's citizens through technology by training the next generation of young software and electronic engineers. Joseph is a true ambassador to social-entrepreneurs and is always willing to help others by passing on critical insight and learnings he has developed whilst pursuing his own innovations.
title: Improving The Future Of Wireless Communications

speaker: {name:'Justin Alvey',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.scrapwind.com/',title:''}]'}
description: Justin is actively involved in renewable energy, since developing a wind turbine from scrap materials during his undergraduate engineering degree. He is now looking into uses of second life EV batteries to create an innovative system for sharing power in rural communities.
title: A Water-Well Inspired Approach To Power In Rural Areas

description: Peter sees green nanotechnology as the engine driving local innovation. As an Ideapreneur, he helps businesses like the design & architecture sector address the impact their creations and operations have on living standards and our environment.
title: 10 Nifty Things YOU Can Do With Nanotechnology

speaker: {name:'Phindile Mangwana',webURLs:'[{url:'www.wessa.org.za',title:'WESSA'}]'}
description: Phindile is the Table Mountain Fund intern at WESSA and his work aims at encouraging young people from previously disadvantaged communities to take part in conservation. “I would like to share a youthful vision about the water crisis in South Africa
title: Socially Orientated Approaches To Conservation

description: Lise is currently the energy writer at Financial Mail. She holds an Honours degree in Economics and believes that the key to solving the challenges facing the world is understanding economic history and the way the world has developed up to now.
title: A New Generation of Wealth

description: Ntombiza was born in the Eastern Cape, matriculated in Buren High – Cape Town - and graduated from TSiBA in 2009. She is currently working as the Marketing Coordinator at TSiBA.
title: The Wilderness Experience

speaker: {name:'Bernellle Verster',webURLs:'[{url:'http://merahmas.co.za',title:'Merah Mas'}]'}
description: Bernelle is a Bioprocess Engineer and a Water Maverick. Her passion is water and social entrepreneurship, because water is the most positive tool we have to catalyse change. She believes an integrated approach to education, resource management and profitability is achievable.
title: Musings of a Water Maverick

description: Tony promotes the use of industrial hemp as a sustainable and eco-friendly solution. Hemp can provide jobs, housing, nutrition and much more while saving energy, trees, agro-chemicals, water and Earth.
title: Hemp: Educate Innovate Cultivate

description: Kershan Pancham is a Film Writer and Director, a Spiritual Healer, and serves as Chairperson for the Community of Mandela Rhodes Scholars. He is studying for his Masters in Philosophy at UCT and is dedicated to helping humanity heal.
title: Mirror Mirror On The Wall: Who Is The Me Of Them All?

speaker: {name:'Leigh Meinert',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.tsiba.org.za/',title:'TSiBA Education'},{url:'http://tedxcapetowned.org/speakers',title:'TEDxCapeTownED website'}]'}
description:
Idea worth spreading: The ASK Model - A Unique Approach to Developing Well Rounded Graduates

Leigh only recently began to consider herself an educator. She's still amazed that, with no educational background whatsoever, she was allowed to co-found SA's youngest and smallest university when she was only 25. A lot of what she and her colleagues did when they set about starting the Tertiary School in Business Administation (TSiBA) 8 years ago was done based on intuition and common sense - which turned out to be a pretty good guide. Leigh is currently pursuing a Masters in Higher Education and she says that she's gone back to study how she should have done it - but she's not serious.
title: Jump University

speaker: {name:'Theresa Mallinson',webURLs:'[{url:'www.freeafricanmedia.com',title:'Free African Media website'}]'}
description: In previous lives, Theresa has waitressed in Cape Town, taught English in Vaduz, and been a sub-editor in Dubai. Now she's the managing editor of Free African Media in Johannesburg. She has the best job in the whole world.
title: Media Freedom in Africa: An Ideal Worth Living For

speaker: {name:'Nathan Heller',webURLs:'[{url:'www.ndhct.com',title:'Nathan's website'}]'}
description: Nathan is an emerging Social Entrepreneur trained in best-practice Participatory Leadership methods and working with local-to-global networks of Social Change and Innovation.
title: Playing to Change the World

speaker: {name:'Justin Friedman',webURLs:'[{url:'forloveofwater.co.za',title:''}]'}
description: Justin is for love of water: FLOW is a movement of people, organizations, Government depts, Corporates, Media, Educators and others linked through their shared commitment to instill a deeper appreciation, understanding and respect for water. The unifying message and commitment communicates an understanding; that in order to nurture the life that we are, as human beings and as shared custodians of planet Earth, need to live and act for love of water.
title: For Love of Water

speaker: {name:'Edwin Roberts',webURLs:'[{url:'www.africa-connect.com',title:''}]'}
description:
Edwin holds an MBA in strategy and marketing and has been nominated as a FutureWorld Guru by Deloitte. After more than a decade in blue-chip organisations, he started WorldCup Business, a company that advised several blue chip organisations during the build-up to the 2010 FIFA World Cup. Three more businesses have followed namely Taxi-TV, Bio-com and more recently Africa-connect, a dedicated provider of high-speed, affordable, reliable broadband internet connectivity.

His motto is “choose your future or become a casualty of it”
title: Share the Vision, Dream and Future Realities of Broadband and Biometrics

speaker: {name:'Simon de Haan',webURLs:'[{url:'www.praekeltfoundation.org',title:'Praekelt Foundation'}]'}
description:
Growing up in the Middle East left an indelible impression on Simon and sparked a passionate interest in community development, entrepreneurship and technology. After completing a B.Eng in Media Technology in the Netherlands Simon worked for several prominent digital agencies before being appointed CTO of a promising internet startup in Amsterdam.

In 2009 Simon moved to South Africa to focus on community development work through the use of technology to improve lives of the less privileged.
title: Making the Invisible Visible

speaker: {name:'Ard Matthews',webURLs:'[{url:'http://ardmatthews.com',title:''}]'}
description: Ard Matthews is known as one of South Africa`s most prolific singer/songwriters and his charismatic stage performances and catchy, heartfelt lyrics have led the way to the phenomenal success of Just Jinjer, who are to date the best selling, most successful rock band in South Africa. He shares the power of simplicity through music and experimentation.
title: Loop de Loop

speaker: {name:'Claire Janisch',webURLs:'[{url:'www.biomimicrysa.co.za',title:'claire[@]biomimicrysa.co.za'},{url:'http://za.linkedin.com/pub/claire-janisch/15/a85/504',title:'Claire on LinkedIn'},{url:'www.biomimicrysa.co.za',title:'BiomimicrySA'}]'}
description: Claire founded and heads up biomimicrySA, and is a trainer for the International Biomimicry Professionals Program. She is also the co-creator of the Genius Lab, an organisation inspiring innovation for organisations and individuals.
title: Genius of Water

speaker: {name:'Preven Chetty',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.wessa.org.za/',title:'WESSA'}]'}
description: Preven works for WESSA facilitating accredited environmental education courses nationally aimed at building environmental skills capacity in South Africa. He leads the River Project which seeks to engage communities all along SA's rivers in caring for our waterways.
title: The River

speaker: {name:'Patrick Kayton',webURLs:'[{url:'www.cognician.com',title:'Cognician'}]'}
description: Patrick is the co-founder of Cognician, an application that augments your thinking by guiding you through challenges with thought provoking questions. The app represents the best that he and his brother and business partner, Barry, have learned about how to put ideas in people's heads.
title: Going With The Flow

speaker: {name:'Craig Whyte',webURLs:'[{url:'www.artlab.co.za',title:'The Artlab'}]'}
description: Craig Whyte has a long history of innovation and creativity at the forefront of the digital graphics industry. From pioneering colour copying in SA at the age of 21, he has since delivered several digital firsts for the country, a children’s TV series and digital jukeboxes. He now owns the ArtLab, which is at the very cutting edge of the industry, using the finest technology available to open new horizons in creative digital imaging, specialising in custom decor applications, photography and fine art - all produced using the best environmentally friendly technology.
title: A Victim Of Circus Time

speaker: {name:'Caron von Zeil',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.facebook.com/RECLAIMCAMISSA',title:'Reclaim Camissa'}]'}
description:
Caron von Zeil, the founder and director of RECLAIM CAMISSA has a Master's degree in Environmental Planning and Landscape Architecture, from the University of Cape Town. She is a complexity thinker, systems designer, urbanist and an activist for the environment, social justice and peace.

Reclaim Camissa is part of the World Design Capital 2014 bid.
title: Reclaiming Camissa

speaker: {name:'Alison Lewis',webURLs:'[{url:'www.crystal.uct.ac.za',title:'Alison.Lewis[@]uct.ac.za'},{url:'www.crystal.uct.ac.za',title:'Crystallization and Precipitation Unit'}]'}
description:
Alison is a registered Professional Engineer and the Director of the Crystallization and Precipitation Unit at the University of Cape Town.

The Research Unit works nationally and internationally as specialists in the field of Industrial Crystallization and Precipitation, especially in hydrometallurgical applications.
title: Be bold and mighty forces will come to your aid

description: Anthony Turton is a thought leader interested in solving seemingly intractible problems. He is the author of Shaking Hands with Billy and was the SAB Environmentalist of the Year (2010). He is currently applying his skills in the management of water and energy as a flux, as a consultant to the mining and financial sectors on the need for a New Social Charter for Mining in water-constrained areas that are culturally and ecologically sensitive.
title: Reinventing Uncivilisation

speaker: {name:'Clinton Smith',webURLs:'[{url:'www.cosmesis.co.za',title:'Cosmesis'}]'}
description: With his passion and skill at making the unbelievable a reality within the confines of a cinematic and entertainment environment, Clinton Smith was born to become a maker of Character Fx. Founder of COSMESIS Advanced Prosthetics Studio , where they aim to not only do FX for the film & television industry, but also focus on medical prosthetics for disabled people that cannot afford these costly applications.
title: Redesigning the Perception of Beauty

speaker: {name:'Michael Markovina',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.movingsushi.com/',title:'Moving Sushi'},{url:'http://www.wcs.org/',title:'Wildlife Conservation Society '},{url:'www.tedxseapoint.com',title:'TEDxSeaPoint'}]'}
description:
Michael has a passion for the ocean, and therefore holds a MSc in Ichthyology and Fisheries Science. While working for the Wildlife Conservation Society (WCS) Michael was in charge of all marine based expeditions. He developed the Moving Sushi Marine Resource Expedition as a means to discover inspiring people and global solutions to fisheries management and conservation.

After this talk, Mike and partner Linda Schonknecht agreed that the TEDx platform is a great way to further showcase the inspiring people they met on their journey, and TEDxSeaPoint was born.
title: Moving Sushi

speaker: {name:'Phakama Pyoos',webURLs:'[{url:'http://siyakhonaafrica.wordpress.com/',title:'Siyakhona Project'}]'}
description:
Phakama Pyoos, a resident of Mfuleni, was selected last year to partake in the Siyakhona Project, a project that trains young people from disadvantaged backgrounds to be video journalists. Phakama now runs her own video production company, working for large corporate clients, but still aims to use community media to create change around critical social issues like xenophobia, corruption, HIV-Aids and homophobia.

Earlier this year she presented the Siyakhona Project to the World Design Capital Judges as part of Cape Town’s bid for the title in 2014. She spoke at TEDxMfuleni 2011
title: Phakama Pyoos

speaker: {name:'Nathan Roberts',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K5EtgpD6zHw&feature=share',title:'Sibanya Township Restaurant'}]'}
description: At the age of 21, Nathan Roberts and a friend founded and started Sibanya Township Restaurant in Hout Bay. Having grown up in Hout Bay, Nathan was fully aware of growing up in a segregated environment. Together with this friend Randy McKnight, who wanted to be the chef but could not read or write, they developed Sibanya Township Restaurant in an attempt to empower Randy, and address the racial segregation of the community. Nathan has been selected as one of South Africa’s 100 Brightest Young Minds in 2011 and is currently completing his Postgraduate Diploma in Entrepreneurship. He spoke at TEDxMfuleni 2011.
title: Nathan Roberts

speaker: {name:'Mokena Makeka',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.makekadesigns.com/',title:'Makeka Design Lab'}]'}
description:
Mokena Makeka is an architect who founded, and is creative director and MD, of Makeka Design Lab. A graduate of the UCT School of Architecture who, according to Design Indaba 2010 (where he recently spoke), is passionate about creating a sound African aesthetic that serves the public and client, bringing dignity and grace to the built environment.

He sits on the World Economic Forum’s Global Agenda Council for Design, is an external examiner at the Columbia University School of architecture and lectures at the University of Cape Town. He spoke at TEDxMfuleni 2011.
title: Mokena Makeka

description: Ntombiza was born in the Eastern Cape, matriculated in Buren High – Cape Town - and graduated from TSiBA in 2009. She is currently working as the Marketing Coordinator at TSiBA.
title: Ntombiza Lingani

speaker: {name:'Simphiwe Mahlanyana',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.uwfund.org/',title:'Umthombo Wesizwe'}]'}
description:
Simphiwe has a certificate in Office Administration and Marketing and has much experience in life and personal empowerment. He is passionate about good music and last year was in the Top 100 in Cape Town for South African Idols. Apart from his singing, he is a full-time Project Coordinator for an NGO called Umthombo Wesizwe Children’s Project where he manages some areas of the Cultural Diversity Intelligence Programme for pre-teens. 

When he’s at home, you’ll normally find him in the kitchen exploring and mixing never-ever-imagined ingredients to make a legendary meal or you will find him posing for a camera using different furniture in-house. He lives life openly and is indeed an open book with answers written on his forehead even before he’s questioned.
title: Simphiwe Mahlanyana
TEDxCapeTown in a nutshell
TEDxCapeTown in a nutshell - long version (607MB)

speaker: {name:'Ricky Lee Gordon',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.a-word-of-art.co.za/',title:'/ A WORD OF ART'},{url:'www.writeonafrica.org',title:''}]'}
description: Ricky is an Artist and Curator, and it is his intent to inspire through art. He is the Founder of /A WORD OF ART and Write on Africa. Ricky believes that life and art are about practice, learning from the world and mostly looking within and learning from yourself and humbling yourself to allow for growth.
title: Inspiring Ourselves to Inspire Others to Inspire Change
TED and TEDx explained
Why TEDxMfuleni?

speaker: {name:'Michael Markovina',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.movingsushi.com/',title:'Moving Sushi'},{url:'http://www.wcs.org/',title:'Wildlife Conservation Society '},{url:'www.tedxseapoint.com',title:'TEDxSeaPoint'}]'}

Food Security

speaker: {name:'Soli Philander',webURLs:'[{url:'http://tedxcapetowned.org/speakers',title:'TEDxCapeTownED website'}]'}
description:
Seasoned broadcaster, award-winning actor, television presenter, director, comedian, playwright, columnist and motivational speaker.

Idea worth spreading: Learning for Laughs

Born and bred in Elsies River, Soli’s roots are firmly planted in the Cape. After matriculating from John Ramsay Secondary School in Bishop Lavis, he says he “fell into acting” after accompanying a friend to an audition. Since then he has performed around South Africa in all the key theatres. He has also performed internationally in Sweden, The Netherlands, America, the UK, Swaziland and Namibia. Over the course of his prestigious career Soli has hosted numerous radio shows and formed part of the original 567 CapeTalk line-up in 1997.
title: Soli Philander - What My Children Taught Me

speaker: {name:'Xola Soliki ',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.tedxcapetowned.org',title:'TEDxCapeTownED website'},{url:'http://www.goldpe.org.za/',title:'GOLD Peer Education'}]'}
description: Idea worth spreading: The power of peers Xola is an 18 year old male who was selected as a GOLD Peer Educator when he was in grade 10 due to his leadership potential. He lives in Kraaifontein, a community riddled with poverty, gangsterism and crime. Xola grew up in a single parent household with four siblings. Before joining GOLD, he used to think it was “only his opinion that mattered”. He now sees himself as a positive role model for his generation and he has been able to influence the decisions of his peers in a measurable way. Xola has encouraged his peers to finish school like himself and to study further after matric despite the tough circumstances that young people in his school and community face. He plans to start a Theatre for youth in his community, to get them involved in something positive. Xola is passionate about spreading an idea to help others to “think out of the box” about the power of positive peer pressure to bring about real change at an individual, group and community level.
title: Xola Sdiki - The Power of Peers

speaker: {name:'Mamphela Ramphele',webURLs:'[{url:'http://tedxcapetowned.org/speakers',title:'TEDxCapeTownED website'}]'}
description:
Activist, Author, Academic, Businesswoman and Medical Doctor

Idea worth spreading: How can you be an education activist?

Dr Ramphele is a South African academic, businesswoman and medical doctor and was an anti-apartheid activist. She was one of the founders of the Black Consciousness Movement, along with Steve Biko. Mamphela Ramphele was voted 55th in the Top 100 Great South Africans in 2004. She is currently chairperson of Circle Capital Ventures and serves as a Director of Medi-Clinic Corporation Limited and Business Partners.
title: Dr Mamphela Ramphele - Rising to our Citizens' Responsibility

speaker: {name:'Malinga Nopote ',webURLs:'[{url:'http://tedxcapetowned.org/speakers',title:'TEDxCapeTownED website'}]'}
description:
Idea worth spreading: Excellence requires commitment. Commitment requires trust.

Malinga Nopote trained as a secondary school teacher at UWC and has been teaching in the Western Cape since 1995. She was appointed principal of Sinenjongo High School in Joe Slovo, Cape Town in July 2010. She and her team increased the matric pass rate at Sinenjongo from 44% in 2009, to 98% in 2010, and 88% in 2011. Her vision is to produce well-educated learners who can be independent thinkers. Malinga wants to see South Africa benefit from ‘the best leaders’ - particularly leaders from disadvantaged backgrounds – appointed into governance positions.
title: Malinga Nopote - Excellence Through Trust

speaker: {name:'Christoph Hagspihl',webURLs:'[{url:'http://tedxcapetowned.org/speakers',title:'TEDxCapeTownED website'}]'}
description:
Idea worth spreading: Graduates in the township

Christoph grew up in Joburg and went on to study mathematics at UCT. He is currently completing his masters in mathematical finance. Because of his passion for education and bridging the divide, he is also teaching full time at a township school called Mfuleni High School. His involvement with Mfuleni has opened the door to a number of further partnerships.
title: Christoph Hagspihl - Graduates in the Township

speaker: {name:'Samantha Beningfield',webURLs:'[{url:'https://twitter.com/sunsandaughters',title:'Suns and Daughters on Twitter:@sunsandaughters'},{url:'https://twitter.com/sambeningfield',title:'Samantha on twitter:@sambeningfield'},{url:'http://sunsanddaughters.wordpress.com/',title:'Suns and Daughters'}]'}
description: Samantha Beningfield is a fourth year medical student at the University of Cape Town, and loves living in a digs with six other wonderful students, even when she misses her sugarcane farm in KwaZulu Natal. She has loved being involved in ‘Suns & Daughters’ over the last year and cannot wait to see it grow even larger.
title: Samantha Beningfield - A one for one life

description: My name is Thabiso “mental apartheid”, and my talk is based on my experiences as a young boy growing up in township post-apartheid and attending a school in a Camps Bay suburb, having a comparison of the two worlds. My talk discusses the psychological damage which segregation and racism has shaped the mindset of South Africans, black people today still feeling inferior and incapable to achieve certain things and how that is proved by the slow development in our townships through our social and economic life, white South Africans and all the prejudices that still exists based on ones background.
title: Thabiso Mkosi - Mental Apartheid

speaker: {name:'Litha Maqungo',webURLs:'[{url:'https://twitter.com/lithamaqungo',title:'Litha on Twitter: @lithamaqungo'}]'}
description:
Litha Maqungo is a fifteen year old environmental activist who's a Consider Us ambassador and 50|50 youth presenter. Having attended COP15 at the age of 13 and represented the youth in a room of influential decision makers in Copenhagen. She later went on to have lunch at the president's house, attend COP17 and come up with the idea to have well-known group Freshlyground re-write their hit song 'Doo be Doo' for COP17. She believes the youth are the future of Africa and it's time we all come together for change.

Litha's talk at TEDxYouth@CapeTown:
Connecting for Change 

We're all connected not only as Africans but as individuals all over the world. In order for us to achieve change and sustainable development in Africa we need to use our connectivity. I'll be talking about how I've seen connectivity in action in Copenhagen and also in my work as a 50|50 presenter. I'll also be talking about how connectivity is the tipping point for every big idea. It's time for change to become a global phenomenon.
title: Litha Maqungo - Connecting for Change

speaker: {name:'Nicola Soekoe',webURLs:'[{url:'www.withlovefromtheworld.org',title:'with love from the world'},{url:'www.withlovefromnicola.wordpress.com',title:'Nicola's blog'}]'}
description:
"I am an African for her wildness quenches my spirit and brings me closer to the source of life" - Wayne Visser

Nineteen year old Nicola Soekoe bursts with patriotism, passion and optimism for South Africa and Africa. As the recent founder of the Non-Profit Organisation, "...with love from the world", which will provide high-school scholarships for underprivileged South African youth, Nicola hopes to one day play a significant role in uplifting our continent.

Nicola's talk at TEDxYouth@CapeTown:
"My Relationship Status with Africa"
title: Nicola Soekoe - My relationship status with Africa

speaker: {name:'Harriet Stockwell',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.harrietstockwell.blogspot.com/',title:'Harriet's blog'}]'}
description:
I recently graduated from the Cape Peninsula University of Technology in Graphic Design. I am an enthusiastic 22 year old geared to making positive changes through design. The Eco Design Initiative changed my whole outlook on design. All that was taught to me about design being 'sell sell sell a product', has now changed to make 'change change change in people's lives'. Design is possibly the most powerful tool to change minds, lives and living. If Design thinking is just powered in the right direction, positive social upliftment and innovation could sprout up all over the world. It is the simple idea that is the most effective and what the Eco Design Initative Challenge taught me was the best way to get that simple idea is to involve those whom you designing for. Design for me used to be an inward perspective but it is now an outward approach. Design is not about the Designer, it is about the people whom you design for. Africa is the greatest place to begin to design for social upliftment and innovation. Africa is so rich in design, it just needs a little guidance in the right direction.

Africa is in me, it is in my home, it is in my community. I was not born in Africa neither am I a South African citizen but I have only ever known what it is to be African. Africa is my home, it is my teacher, it is who I am. Whenever I come home from traveling overseas and I see Table Mountain I know I am home. Hearing an African accent while overseas makes me feel close to home. Africa is a beat, a vibe, an energy that flows through every single on of us that live here. It is what connects us and makes us African. It is that connection that should fuel design in Africa. Design can eradicate that which was left by the colonial powers and the apartheid era if everyone is involved. Community is key in designing and if design had to focus on social upliftment and innovation with the involvement of the community one is designing for, then Africa could be a sustainable rich continent. The theme Africa in me relates to who I am, how I design and who I design with. I would like to share my experience with the Eco Design Initiative challenge as well as my own personal thoughts relating to the theme Africa in Me at TEDxYouth@CapeTown.
title: Harriet Stockwell - a social approach to sustainabi...

description:
My name is Mogamat Dayaan Salie, cool people call me MDS, or just Dayaan. I'm 16, young but with vision. They tell me I talk to much, I tell them they don't talk enough. I enjoy spending time with friends & Family, listening to music, reading, watching movies, pc games and the usual teenage stuff. In addition I love arguing (debating) about history and religion, where I always play the devil's advocate. I'm also somewhat of a young Businessman, so watch out, I might just make you a deal you can't refuse.

So that's me, hope you come and watch me and my fellow TEDxsters speak our minds. And remember, clap really loudly when the MDS comes on stage;)
title: Dayaan Salie - Africa, In Me?

description:
Lungile was born in 1987, 11th of July in a village in South Africa. He comes from the Xhosa culture. He grew and studied in Cape Town. At the age of 11 he fell in love with hip hop, which he sees as a tool to spread positive messages. Since then he has been performing poetry, theatre and music across the Western Cape and Eastern Cape. He recruits young ones to participate in the spoken word movement and has successfully written songs and discovered some of the most well-known young performers in the Western Cape. He is also a fashion designer and activist, because of his involvement in some challenges (gangsterism, xenophobia and teenage alcoholism) surrounding his area. Recently he is working on a project which will mainly focus on the spoken word (poets, musicians, motivational speakers, stand-up comedians, and audio dramas). He is also working on his album, which is about Africa.

Lungile's talk at TEDxYouth@CapeTown:
"African Development"
title: Lungile Ludidi - Africa

speaker: {name:'Henko Roukema',webURLs:'[{url:'www.mikehorn.com/en/yep',title:'Young Explorers Program Website'},{url:'http://blogs.gotravel24.com/ecoh',title:'Henko's blog'},{url:'http://pangaea-yep.com/Henko',title:'Henko's Pangaea profile'}]'}
description:
Henko(19) has a passion for adventure, ice swimming and living life to the fullest. He is the SA representative of the Mike Horn PANGAEA Young Explorers Program and also the founder of YEZA (Young Explorers South Africa) – a club aiming to encourage youths to explore , conserve & help others. He is a current Maritime(navigation) student at CPUT and volunteers as a Big Bay Beach lifeguard.

Henko’s talk at TEDxYouth@CapeTown 2012: AIMing beyond boundaries

“I believe everybody should AIM far beyond our boundaries – literally & figuratively speaking. Personally, I AIM to inspire others and show people what we are capable of achieving if we apply the power of our mind and AIM towards a goal.

During my Young Explorers expeditions to some of the world’s most remote environments we were faced with tough challenges and I soon realized that South Africans have tremendous “SPIRIT” ! If used as an acronym, it spells Self-confidence, Positive attitude, Imagination, Resilience, Initiative & Teamwork. These opportunities to explore countries at the complete other side of the globe certainly changed my perspective on life in South Africa. We have an amazingly beautiful, rich & diverse country with warm & friendly people . I believe that as a nation, we should embrace our “Africa In Me” SPIRIT and be proudly South African!
title: Henko Roukema - AIMing beyond boundaries

speaker: {name:'Murray Gibbon',webURLs:'[{url:'http://tedxcapetowned.org/speakers',title:'TEDxCapeTownED website'}]'}
description:
Idea worth spreading: Building successful school to school partnerships.

Education runs deep in Murray's blood. He's passionate about people - young people in particular - and transforming our country. He has taught at various schools around Cape Town and overseas. Most recently he has pioneered the establishment of the new Maths & Science focus school, Claremont High, in Cape Town, in partnership with Westerford High.
title: Murray Gibbon - Building successful school partnerships

speaker: {name:'Phadiela Cooper',webURLs:'[{url:'http://tedxcapetowned.org/speakers',title:'TEDxCapeTownED website'}]'}
description:
Idea worth spreading: The secrets of success for a township school.

Phadiela Cooper is the principal of a Khayelitsha school, Centre of Science and Technology, the first to make it on to the province’s list of top 10 schools. One of their students achieved six distinctions. The school is one of three STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) facilities in the Western Cape where pupils with an aptitude for maths and science are accepted. The other two facilities are the Cape Academy in Tokai and the new Claremont High School.
title: Phadiela Cooper - No excuses, just success

speaker: {name:'Steve Sherman',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.livingmaths.com/',title:'Living Maths'},{url:'http://tedxcapetowned.org/speakers',title:'TEDxCapeTownED website'}]'}
description:
idea worth spreading: Bringing the world into one classroom

Steve is the Managing Director of an Educational NGO called Living Maths. He teaches approximately 4500 students weekly in schools around Cape Town and now recently, the world. He is passionate about sharing knowledge and empowering young people. He is also a multi-award purchasing educator and was voted third best-looking educational innovator by his mother. He feels that it is his destiny to spread the joy of numbers to anyone who is willing to listen and even to those who are not. He knows Karate, Ju-jitsu and 2 other Japanese words.
title: Steve Sherman - The global classroom, live from South Africa

speaker: {name:'Laura Czerniewicz',webURLs:'[{url:'http://lauraczerniewicz.co.za/',title:'Prof Laura Czerniewicz's website'},{url:'http://tedxcapetowned.org/speakers',title:'TEDxCapeTownED website'}]'}
description:
Idea worth spreading: Why education should be open in all sorts of ways and what to watch out for

An educator, researcher and strategist, Associate Professor Laura Czerniewicz has worked in the field of educational technology at the University of Cape Town for over a decade, previously working in education and publishing in Zimbabwe and South Africa. The founding Director of the Centre for Educational Technology, she is currently the Director of the OpenUCT Initiative leading the university to open up its knowledge resources to all with internet connectivity and engage globally with the open education agenda and scholarly communication issues from a Southern perspective. Her research interests include open education, scholarly communication, digital scholarship, students' digitally-mediated practices, digital identities and the field of learning technology as a scholarly domain. She blogs at lauraczerniewicz.uct.ac.za and tweets as @czernie
title: Laura Czerniewicz - SA needs open education
category: [{name:'learning technology'},{name:'digital identities'},{name:'students' digitally-mediated practices'},{name:'digital scholarship'},{name:'scholarly communication'},{name:'open education'},{name:'Education'},{name:'2012'}]

speaker: {name:'Jos Dirkx',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.girlsandfootballsa.com/',title:'Girls and Football SA'},{url:'http://tedxcapetowned.org/speakers',title:'TEDxCapeTownED website'}]'}
description:
Idea worth spreading: What do Girls, Football and Learning have in common?

Jos Dirkx has lived on five continents and currently resides in South Africa. Her dedication to social justice and gender equality has propelled her participation in projects, debates, fund-raising and campaigning for increased public awareness of women’s rights, and her hands-on experience with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Sudan has furthered her dedication to making social justice and gender equality a worldwide priority. She is the Founder and Director of award-winning Girls & Football SA and passionate about girls' education. Girls and Football SA
title: Jos Dirkx  - Girls, Football and Learning

speaker: {name:'Quite a White Ou',webURLs:'[{url:'www.quiteawhiteou.com',title:'Quite a White Ou'},{url:'http://tedxcapetowned.org/',title:'TEDxCapeTownED website'},{url:'www.learnxhosa.co.za',title:'Ubuntu Bridge'},{url:'http://www.indiegogo.com/the-answer',title:'Quite a White Ou's fundraising campaign: Turning TEDx ideas into Action'}]'}
description:
idea worth spreading: Language learning - bridge to a better world

Craig Makhosi Charnock studied Psychology, Philosophy and Film Studies, with a lifelong career in comedic and dramatic performance on the side. Following an 8 month rural stint as a trainee sangoma, Makhosi’s calling shifted into guiding people through the transformative process of learning to speak Xhosa through his company UBuntu Bridge (www.learnxhosa.co.za), which also facilitates intercultural immersion experiences in rural villages and townships. More recently Craig's musical persona has emerged as Quite a White Ou (www.quiteawhiteou.com), who sings in Xhosa and English, with the intention of breaking down racial stereotypes, inspiring language learning and as potential compensation for the sometimes non-existent salary of a self-employed teacher.
title: Quite a White Ou - Language learning - bridge to a better world

description:
I am Louise, a passionate South African and social entrepreneur who started Symphonia. I have dedicated the next decade of my life to contributing to a radical transformation in the South African education system so that all children in South Africa will have access to quality education by 2022. 

I believe the answer to the education crisis lies with citizens rather than politicians or government officials.

 

My idea worth spreading to present at TEDxCapeTown 2012 is to introduce a radical innovation in the field of CSI, education reform and leadership development that creates opportunities for business leaders to make a significant difference to education whilst developing their leadership skills.
title: Louise Van Rhyn - Life-changing partnerships between school principals and business leaders

speaker: {name:'Rich Mulholland',webURLs:'[{url:'richmulholland.com',title:'Rich's blog'},{url:'http://www.tedxcapetowned.org',title:'TEDxCapeTownED website'}]'}
description:
Idea worth spreading: Escaping educational legacide

Richard kicked off his career as a rock n roll roadie, operating lights for bands such as Iron Maiden and Def Leppard. From there he started SA's largest presentation firm, Missing Link and co-founded 21Tanks, SA's first perspective lab. Richard is a highly regarded speaker. When not addressing many of South Africa's top corporations, he guest lectures on courses for The Cape Graduate School of Business (GSB), and the Gordon Institute of Business Science (GIBS). As well as blogging on richmulholland.com, Richard is a columnist for Longevity and Destiny Man magazines.
title: Rich Mulholland - Escaping educational legacide

speaker: {name:'Tim Noakes',webURLs:'[{url:'http://za.linkedin.com/pub/timothy-noakes/8/b04/294',title:'Tim on LinkedIn'},{url:'http://www.essm.uct.ac.za/',title:'Exercise Science and Sports Medicine website'},{url:'https://twitter.com/ProfTimNoakes',title:'Tim on Twitter: @ProfTimNoakes'}]'}
description:
I am Tim Noakes, co-founder and executive director of the Sports Science Institute of SA, author, respected academic and A1 rated scientist.

I am a Director of UCT/MRC Research Unit for Exercise Science and Sports Medicine, Department of Human Biology, Faculty of Health Science, University of Cape Town. I am also the Professor, Discovery Health Chair of Exercise and Sports Science, University of Cape Town. I have long been acknowledged as an expert in the field of sports and the science of physical exercise. 

 

My idea worth spreading to present at TEDxCapeTown 2012 is about having the right mindset to learn and achieve.
title: Tim Noakes - The mindset to succeed

speaker: {name:'John Gilmour',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.leapschool.org.za/',title:'LEAP Science & Maths Schools'},{url:'http://tedxcapetowned.org/speakers',title:'TEDxCapeTownED website'}]'}
description:
Idea worth spreading: We are failing our kids by focusing on the cognitive and ignoring the emotional

John Gilmour is the Founder of the LEAP Science and Maths Schools. He was Principal of Abbott’s College for five years before leaving to set up the LEAP Science and Maths School. The aim of the LEAP School is to transform the lives of disadvantaged young people, as well as the communities from which they come.
title: John Gilmour - Education for the whole person

speaker: {name:'Leigh Meinert',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.tsiba.org.za/',title:'TSiBA Education'},{url:'http://tedxcapetowned.org/speakers',title:'TEDxCapeTownED website'}]'}
description:
Idea worth spreading: The ASK Model - A Unique Approach to Developing Well Rounded Graduates

Leigh only recently began to consider herself an educator. She's still amazed that, with no educational background whatsoever, she was allowed to co-found SA's youngest and smallest university when she was only 25. A lot of what she and her colleagues did when they set about starting the Tertiary School in Business Administation (TSiBA) 8 years ago was done based on intuition and common sense - which turned out to be a pretty good guide. Leigh is currently pursuing a Masters in Higher Education and she says that she's gone back to study how she should have done it - but she's not serious.
title: Leigh Meinert - The Soul of Education

speaker: {name:'Sam Paddock',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.tedxcapetowned.org',title:'TEDxCapeTownED website'},{url:'http://www.getsmarter.co.za/',title:'Get Smarter'}]'}
description:
Idea worth spreading: What if mothers taught the world?

Sam is the Executive Director of GetSmarter - a high touch online education company that works with Universities to deliver online short courses. The company is 4 years old, and in 2012, now headed by Sam's brother Rob and his 70-person team, will educate over 5,000 students throughout South Africa. With a deep passion for disruption, Sam now heads up GetSmarter's Incubator which amongst other things has initiated projects in mobile maths education, worksheet and lesson plan sharing, a web-based teaching platform and delivery models for online education in township conditions.
title: Sam Paddock - What if Mothers Taught the World?

speaker: {name:'Ian Scott',webURLs:'[{url:'http://tedxcapetowned.org/speakers',title:'TEDxCapeTownED website'}]'}
description:
Idea worth spreading: We desperately need more black graduates. Here is why they are failing. Here is what doesn't work. Here is what might.

Prof. Ian Scott is the director of Academic Development and a professor and deputy dean at the University of Cape Town. He has been a member of the Ministry of Education's Reference Group on Academic Development since 2000. His research and development interests include higher education policy related to teaching-and-learning, curriculum and qualifications frameworks, and comparative models for widening participation in higher education. He is also involved in improving throughput in the Engineering Bachelors Degree.
title: Ian Scott - Failing the majority: The need for higher education to face reality

speaker: {name:'Brent van Rensburg',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.zip-zap.co.za/',title:'Zip Zap Circus School'},{url:'http://tedxcapetowned.org/speakers',title:'TEDxCapeTownED website'}]'}
description:
Idea worth spreading: Your failures are my superstars

Apparently, Brent hates education. He didn't consider himself an educator before the TEDxCapeTownED team convinced him otherwise. Born in 1961 in Cape Town, he started to learn daring aerial skills at the Circus school in Cape Town and for the next 15 years performed internationally. After an accident he decided to leave the performing side and became an acrobatic instructor and conducted circus workshops. At that time he met his future wife and Co-Founder of the Zip Zap circus school Laurence Esteve. In 1992 he and Laurence returned to South Africa and founded the Zip Zap circus school. Brent brings over 20 years of experience and passion for the circus to training young, aspiring Zip Zap performers from all walks of life. Zip Zap Circus School
title: Brent van Rensburg - Your Failures Are Our Superstars

speaker: {name:'Emile Engel',webURLs:'[{url:'www.twitter.com/chocolatemunkee',title:'Emile on Twitter: @chocolatemunkee'},{url:'http://www.rethink-leadership.org/',title:'Re.think Leadership'}]'}
description: I am a trained chemist who is employed at Re.think Leadership, an organisation that I co-founded in 2009. Re.think Leadership's work focuses on dialogue and youth leadership development. We are providing opportunities for high school youth to develop communication skills, engage in challenging dialogue, and explore what it means to be a leader in a world where the traditional beliefs about how to lead and who can lead have been thoroughly shattered. Recently, we have been particularly interested in exposing young people to the wave of innovation that is taking place in the theory and practice of effecting social change. Emile's talk at TEDxYouth@CapeTown: A Playful Look at Social Innovation
title: Emile Engel - A playful look at Social Innovation
TEDxCapeTown 2012: What We Play Is Life

speaker: {name:'Ulrike Rivett',webURLs:'[{url:'www.facebook.com/icommsza',title:'iComms on Facebook'},{url:'http://za.linkedin.com/pub/ulrike-rivett/5/3a2/61a',title:'Ulrike on LinkedIn'},{url:'www.icomms.org',title:'iComms'}]'}
description:
I am Ulrike Rivett, an academic at the University of Cape Town in the Department of Civil Engineering. I arrived in South Africa in 1995 from Germany, to do my postgraduate studies in Cape Town. Since then, I have been privileged to learn through the people and the country of South Africa.

I TEDx because I love to be inspired by inspiring people, to hear that other people had ideas that turned into a real change – to feel the excitement of an enthusiastic speaker and to see the world through their eyes for 15 minutes is a fantastic experience.

My idea worth spreading at TEDxCapeTown 2012 is about the ability to trust the water we drink. It’s about governments delivering services. It’s about our tendency to be depressed by all the 'stuff ups' without coming up with a better solution. It’s about changing how we think.
title: Ulrike Rivett - Trusting the water we drink

description:
I am Winslow. I download lessons, blessings and love - spiritually and emotionally - into journeys through words and sounds and the power held between these two elements.

I weave words into tapestries to ignite the audiences’ passion for poetry and live performance. I am no stranger to the stage and with no fear of expressing my truth, I take the audience through journeys of self-discovery and the pain, ecstasy and freedom that loving your heritage, others and inevitably yourself brings.
title: Winslow Schalkwyk - What We Play Is Life

speaker: {name:'Warren Nilsson',webURLs:'[{url:'http://organizationunbound.org/',title:'Organization Unbound'}]'}
description:
I am Warren Nilsson. I spend most of my time puzzling over how organizations do or don’t foster social innovation. After 10 years doing community development work in the U.S., I moved to Montreal, Canada to do my doctoral research. I’m now on the faculty at the University of Cape Town and am also the co-founder of Organization Unbound.

I TEDx because I have been working with and studying some of the most beautiful and innovative social purpose organizations on this planet. They have taught me a great deal about the generative power of authentic community and I want to share what I have learned.

My idea worth spreading to present at TEDxCapeTown 2012 is that the biggest challenge the world is facing is not how to create change but how to sustain change, and if we want to sustain change we are mostly paying attention to the wrong things, particularly inside our social purpose organizations and social movements.
title: Warren Nilsson - Sustaining Social Change

speaker: {name:'Tim Noakes',webURLs:'[{url:'http://za.linkedin.com/pub/timothy-noakes/8/b04/294',title:'Tim on LinkedIn'},{url:'http://www.essm.uct.ac.za/',title:'Exercise Science and Sports Medicine website'},{url:'https://twitter.com/ProfTimNoakes',title:'Tim on Twitter: @ProfTimNoakes'}]'}
description:
I am Tim Noakes, co-founder and executive director of the Sports Science Institute of SA, author, respected academic and A1 rated scientist.

I am a Director of UCT/MRC Research Unit for Exercise Science and Sports Medicine, Department of Human Biology, Faculty of Health Science, University of Cape Town. I am also the Professor, Discovery Health Chair of Exercise and Sports Science, University of Cape Town. I have long been acknowledged as an expert in the field of sports and the science of physical exercise. 

 

My idea worth spreading to present at TEDxCapeTown 2012 is about having the right mindset to learn and achieve.
title: Tim Noakes - Challenging Beliefs

speaker: {name:'Sue Harrison',webURLs:'[{url:'http://za.linkedin.com/pub/sue-harrison/34/b78/a13',title:'Sue on LinkedIn'},{url:'https://www.facebook.com/groups/354550811270789/',title:'CeBER on Facebook'},{url:'http://www.ceber-uct.org/',title:'CeBER'}]'}
description:
I am Sue Harrison, a professor in Chemical Engineering and the South African Research Chair in Bioprocess Engineering.

My research falls between the disciplines of microbiology, life sciences and chemical engineering, and my research passion draws on these disciplines to inform bioprocesses to benefit society, the environment and the economy.

I TEDx because I am a strong proponent that by sharing ideas, debating them and developing them, we improve our combined outputs, far more than working in isolation. When we work at the boundaries of disciplines, we draw on the wealth of knowledge in each.

My idea worth spreading to present at TEDxCapeTown 2012 is the potential for using integrated bioprocesses for conversion of a range of byproducts to commodity products, value-added products and benign wastes using the underlying concepts of industrial ecology. Often these integrated processes can form biorefineries, allowing multiple products from cheap complex resources or the waste resource. Such biorefineries hold great promise for South Africa and will only be realised by working across boundaries and disciplines.
title: Sue Harrison - Integrating bioprocesses

speaker: {name:'Shannon Royden-Turner',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.informalsouth.co.za/',title:'Informal South website'},{url:'http://www.linkedin.com/in/shannoninformalsouth',title:'Shannon on LinkedIn'}]'}
description:
I am Shannon, driven by a mission to inspire transformation by continually seeking innovative solutions to issues of social and environmental inequality and injustice. My social enterprise, in / formal south, focuses on integrating diverse disciplines to collectively question the notion that urban development is merely a spatial concern to be addressed exclusively with technical and physical solutions.

I TEDx because it has the ability to support inter and transdisciplinary potential by enabling people from diverse backgrounds to access ideas that to date remain contained within specific disciplines, research fields or cultures. It has the potential to be both universal as well as locally attuned, allowing people to see connections beyond their immediate environments.

My idea worth spreading to present at TEDxCapeTown 2012: reconceptualising the city from the bottom up seeks to shift our perceptions away from an ideal of radical change towards one of radical incrementalism where informal settlements are seen as assets within the city. This requires that we move beyond a paradigm of eradication towards one of intervention capable of addressing the qualitative aspects of informal city making.
title: Shannon Royden Turner - Redefining assets

speaker: {name:'Richard Marshall',webURLs:'[{url:'www.facebook.com/djmarshallct',title:'Richard Marshall on Facebook'},{url:'www.noisefloor.co.za',title:'NoiseFloor website'},{url:'http://soundcloud.com/dj-marshall-1',title:'Richard on Soundcloud'},{url:'https://twitter.com/dj_r_marshall',title:'Richard on Twitter: @dj_r_marshall'},{url:'http://www.capetownalive.com/cape-town-alive/interviews/cape-town-electronic-music-industry-through-the-eyes-of-richard-marshall-ryan-sullivan.html',title:'Cape Town electronic music industry through the eyes of Richard Marshall and Ryan Sullivan (CapeTownAlive article)'}]'}
description:
After running a fledgling DJ Company throughout high school, he moved to Cape Town in early 2000 and immediately took up residence playing the infamous Strutt parties at the Cape’s most reputable house music club, The Fez.

Through successful music productions and an increasingly open minded approach to music, Richard’s DJ career moved into the great outdoors where sets were being performed at all of the Cape’s major music festivals; Rocking the Daisies, Earthdance, Origin, Vortex, Global Breakthrough, Alien Safari, Rezonance and MCQP where, along with Shaun Westcott, music direction is handled by him.

In 2011 Richard wrote a synopsis for a proposed hard cover, coffee table book called ‘Dancing in the Dark’ and is currently in negotiations to have this published (being published mid-late 2013). The book will be an in depth look at the history of South African dance music culture, from humble beginnings in the warehouses of rave culture to the multi-million rand, superstar producing industry it is now, and everything in between.

With interviews from the people behind the scenes from as long as 23 years ago, the book promises to leave no grimy stone unturned, an exposé on one of the shadiest businesses in business that has brought more joy, fear, money and despair to more people than almost any other kind. Richard also works as a freelance copywriter and journalist for Tonic International and Resident Advisor, among many others.
title: Richard Marshall - The electronic music scene in South Africa

speaker: {name:'Peter Greenwall',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=en-sgdNoowg',title:'How to Capitalise on any crisis'},{url:'http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E7GHKzWEA6U',title:'Black Note – (about breaking the rules responsibly)  '},{url:'http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oG7vdShDkVk',title:'Frustration For Sale –  (about turning frustrations into business ideas)  '},{url:'www.teenentrepreneur.co.za',title:'TeenEntrepreneur'},{url:'http://www.scribd.com/doc/2020695/Logical-Stupidity-INNOVATION-by-navigating-through-nonsense',title:'Free short copy of book: Logical Stupidity'},{url:'http://za.linkedin.com/pub/peter-greenwall/10/647/5a3',title:'Peter on LinkedIn'},{url:'https://twitter.com/petergreenwall',title:'Peter on Twitter: @PeterGreenwall'},{url:'http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HhfOFkaHkww',title:'About innovation in internet dating'}]'}
description:
I am Peter Greenwall, innovation consultant, corporate songwriter, author and errorthoughtical engineer. I believe that if entrepreneurship and innovation training is going to stand a chance of changing South Africa then it needs to be presented in a way that's accessible to all - through music, comedy and reference points suitable for each target group. 

Coming from a showbiz background (my musical scores featured on World Cup opening ceremonies, Miss World Pageants, London musicals and stage shows for corporates) I am known for my engaging multi-media musical presentations on sustainable innovation and 'PIFYAFFING' or Pulling Ideas From Your Asspirations For FINancial Gain. Inside my light-hearted approach are lessons on creating a culture of innovation and capitalising on change. 

I also wrote a book 'Logical stupidity - innovation by navigating through nonsense', which has been downloaded 20,349 times and can be found on Amazon's best sellers rank in the position of 9,854,850. To date, I've sold 43 copies, of which I've bought 30 myself. I also continue to write no-hit wonders like 'Songs That Nothing Ever Happened To', which has gone anti-viral on YouTube with 243 views since 2009.

My idea worth spreading to present at TEDxCapeTown 2012 is that failure and unlikely places are key ingredients of innovation. I have now found my niche as an innovation consultant, showing corporates how to break failure down to make more things up. This is the back story behind my chosen topic of 'Getting inside ‘WTF?!’ to capitalise on multiple types of failure.
title: Peter Greenwall - Learning from Failure

speaker: {name:'Monique Schiess',webURLs:'[{url:'https://twitter.com/AfrikaBurn',title:'AfrikaBurn on Twitter: @AfrikaBurn'},{url:'https://www.facebook.com/afrikaburn',title:'AfrikaBurn on Facebook'},{url:'http://www.afrikaburn.com/',title:'AfrikaBurn'}]'}
description:
I am Monique. After six and a half years in the desert, I have a doctorate in driving rebar pegs into rock and shale and a PhD in the economics of artistic chaos and wrangling itinerant misfits and renegades. Otherwise known as the original and still active co-ordinator of AfrikaBurn, I see myself as a fire starter of sorts, an instigator and incubator of creative projects.

I make sport of poking people in their creative ribs. I believe that fun, and waking up creativity, is a most powerful vector for change in this world! I was also a partner in the Mother City Queer Projects, have two degrees in Environmental Science and Social Anthropology and had an incarnation as a game ranger.

My idea worth spreading to present at TEDxCapeTown 2012 is around building snowballs of engagement and practicing imagining.
title: Monique Schiess - Practising imagining

speaker: {name:'Mbali Vilakazi',webURLs:'[{url:'https://twitter.com/apoetryofliving',title:'Mbali on Twitter: @apoetryofliving'},{url:'http://mbalivilakazi.com/',title:'Mbali Vilakazi's website'}]'}
description:
I am Mbali Vilakazi, an award-winning poet, performer and creative facilitator. My practice is inspired and informed by the ideas of ‘the personal as political’ and ‘the body as intervention’. As both witness and participant, I work with the specific intent to render visible the most invisible parts of our conversations, our communities and our humanity. I am a fragment of open still catching the light.

I TEDx because creativity is a vast and significant inheritance. Healing and transformative - it is a powerful and useful tool. It is something worth celebrating, and something worth sharing.

My idea worth spreading to present at TEDxCapeTown 2012 is that the process of creating poetry has certain principles that can be adapted into systems of living. Through the act of re-creating how we use language, we are able to re-create our very lives, we are able to reframe our experience of it. It offers us the opportunity to process and navigate the world differently. My talk is entitled 'The process is poetry / poetry is the process'.
title: TEDxCapeTown - Mbali Vilakazi - Poetry is the Process

speaker: {name:'Martin Tai Lyhne Jensen',webURLs:'[{url:'http://ciid.dk/education/portfolio/idp11/students/martin-jensen/',title:'Copenhagen Institute of Interaction Design'}]'}
description:
I am Martin. I would describe myself as a humanist by nature, creative generalist by education and Interaction Designer by profession. I am interested in the hands-on people-centered exploration of technology, social action and the critical application of design to playfully prototype unbelievable ideas into powerful reality.

I TEDx because I believe in demystifying and democratizing technology and hope to pilot it towards the inspired imagination and skillful hands of individuals and communities who are ready to create the change they believe in.

My idea worth spreading to present at TEDxCapeTown 2012 is that the true potential of technology is too great to be trapped within the imagination of technologists. My talk is called 'hitchhiking open technology towards local ingenuity'.
title: Martin Tai Lyhne Jensen - Hitchhiking open technology towards local ingenuity

description:
I am Louise, a passionate South African and social entrepreneur who started Symphonia. I have dedicated the next decade of my life to contributing to a radical transformation in the South African education system so that all children in South Africa will have access to quality education by 2022. 

I believe the answer to the education crisis lies with citizens rather than politicians or government officials.

 

My idea worth spreading to present at TEDxCapeTown 2012 is to introduce a radical innovation in the field of CSI, education reform and leadership development that creates opportunities for business leaders to make a significant difference to education whilst developing their leadership skills.
title: Louise van Rhyn - Changing The Course Of Education

speaker: {name:'Lauren Gillis',webURLs:'[{url:'http://relate.org.za/',title:'Relate Trust'},{url:'https://www.facebook.com/RelateBracelets',title:'Relate on Facebook'}]'}
description:
I am Lauren Gillis. I was born and raised in Johannesburg, where a strong commitment to humanity and social justice was instilled in me from an early age.

After studying social work at the University of the Witwatersrand, my 30 year career evolved into forming businesses and philanthropic organizations committed to supporting individuals in reaching their greatest potential. It’s amazing how something so small can do something so big.

 

I TEDx because I believe that we are all connected, and that each of us has the responsibility and privilege to be an agent of social change. I am passionate that a small handmade connector, a simple string of beads, has remarkable power to restore dignity, hope and resilience to humanity.

My idea worth spreading at TEDxCapeTown 2012 is how we can all create opportunities that change lives, sometimes by doing the smallest things.
title: Lauren Gillis - Redefining Philanthropy

speaker: {name:'Justin R Melville',webURLs:'[{url:'https://twitter.com/JustinRMelville',title:'Justin on Twitter: @JustinRMelville'},{url:'http://za.linkedin.com/in/justinrmelville',title:'Justin on LinkedIn'},{url:'http://get.airbornemusic.com/',title:'Airborne Music'}]'}
description:
I am Justin R. Melville, delivered by a doctor in a tuxedo, self-taught designer, intellectual capitalist and creator of Airborne.

I TEDx because the most important thing about ideas is sharing them and TED is the perfect platform to do that, in a deeply personal and authentic fashion.

My idea worth spreading at TEDxCapeTown 2012 is ways for you and I to shape the future of the music business by sharing experiences and supporting the stuff we love.
title: Justin R Melville - Rethinking the Music Industry

speaker: {name:'Lara Foot-Newton',webURLs:'[{url:'www.baxter.co.za',title:'Baxter Theatre'}]'}
description:
I am Lara, an award-winning playwright, writer and director. I was born and grew up in Pretoria, but in 2005 relocated from Johannesburg to Cape Town with my family to take up the position of Resident Director and Dramaturg at the Baxter Theatre. In January 2010, I was appointed CEO and Director of the Baxter.

I completed my BA (Hons) degree at Wits University in 1989 and in 2007 I attained my master’s degree at the University of Cape Town. I have directed over 40 professional productions, 29 of which have been new South African plays. I also founded the Barney Simon Young Directors and Writers Festivals and have been integral in the development of more than 35 new South African plays. My passion is the development of new indigenous work, young writers and directors.

My idea worth spreading to present at TEDxCapeTown 2012 is the value of theatre to promote honesty, telling stories to re-write the plot of our lives.
title: Lara Foot - Rewriting the plot of our lives

speaker: {name:'Hélène Smit',webURLs:'[{url:'http://helenesmit.wordpress.com/beneath/',title:'Hélène's book: Beneath 'Exploring the unconscious in individuals''},{url:'http://www.feather.co.za/',title:'Feather's website'},{url:'https://www.facebook.com/beneathbetweenandbeyond',title:''Beneath' on Facebook'},{url:'http://za.linkedin.com/pub/helene-smit/a/201/a4b',title:'Hélène on LinkedIn'},{url:'http://www.helenesmit.wordpress.com/',title:'Hélène's blog'}]'}
description:
I am Hélène. I have spent 25 years of my life as a teacher and researcher in the field of psychology and relationships. Fifteen of those years were spent teaching curious and challenging MBA and other students of leadership at the UCT Graduate School of Business.

I am also the Programme Director for the first National Diploma in Facilitation offered by the South African College of Applied Psychology. Through my business, Feather Associates (Pty) Ltd, I've worked with many South African organizations, facilitating people processes about issues that lie beneath the surface and need to be carefully brought into the conversation.

My idea worth sharing to present at TEDxCapeTown 2012 is that much of our behaviour is driven by the unconscious mind, individually and collectively. In order to stop destroying ourselves, our communities and our planet, we as humans need to have a three dimensional approach - working 'beneath' (an ethical and deep relationship with our selves and particularly with our unconscious selves), 'between' (co-operative relationships with others and an awareness of the collective unconscious) and 'beyond' (a connection with our home and our fellow life forms - the earth, the air, the oceans and the other species that live on our planet).
title: Helene Smit - Uncovering the unconscious

speaker: {name:'Chris Loker',webURLs:'[{url:'https://www.facebook.com/waterfinancial',title:'Water Financial on Facebook'},{url:'https://twitter.com/WaterFinancial',title:'Chris on Twitter: @WaterFinancial '},{url:'http://za.linkedin.com/pub/chris-loker/0/18b/323',title:'Chris on LinkedIn'},{url:'http://www.waterfinancial.biz/',title:'Water Financial'}]'}
description:
I am Chris Loker, previously a bank/investment exec who now consults to a range of financial services companies on business strategy. I am the founder of a sustainable finance company and have interests in other entrepreneurial ventures including wellness and entertainment. I have a Business Science degree from the University of Cape Town and other qualifications in finance. In 1990 I led a South African delegation to an international student conference in Japan on sustainable development and feel it's about time I got off the fence. 

I TEDx because, despite the performance anxiety of presenting, I think its an invaluable forum to challenge the prevailing mindset, particularly in business and most especially in the financial services sector. Solving many of the world's social and environmental challenges will require a re-orientation of the present economic models which in turn requires a transformation of the financial services sector. This can only happen by conversations on money moving from the fringe into mainstream, and to change something you need to first understand it.

My idea worth spreading at TEDxCapeTown 2012 is that the money industry is a essentially a simple one despite the mystique and opacity that the protagonists surround it in, so that they can charge more. Financial institutions should be in the background, enabling the real economy, not at the forefront as it is now. This transformation can only take place when individual savers and investors recognize their collective power and insist on greater accountability for the flow of money. We need change catalysts.
title: Chris Loker - Creating sustainable finance

speaker: {name:'Alan Knott-Craig',webURLs:'[{url:'https://twitter.com/alanknottcraig',title:'Alan on Twitter: @AlanKnottCraig'},{url:'http://www.mxit.com/index.html',title:'Mxit'},{url:'http://worldofavatar.com/',title:'World Of Avatar'}]'}
description:
I am Alan, founder of World of Avatar and CEO of Mxit, Africa’s largest social network. I am a qualified Chartered Accountant (SA). Between 2003 and 2006 I co-founded five companies in the mobile services sector and in 2006 I was appointed managing director of iBurst, a broadband network operator in South Africa.

In April 2008 I published Don’t Panic, a best selling book aimed at persuading emigrant South Africans to return home. In June 2008 I then founded The Trust, an NGO focused on assisting charities access skills and capital. In 2009, I was named as a Young Global Leader by the World Economic Forum. In June 2012 I published Mobinomics; the story of Mxit and mobile in Africa.

My idea worth spreading to present at TEDxCapeTown 2012 is about the impact of anonymity in low-income communities in South Africa, particularly as it applies to mobile social networks.
title: Alan Knott Craig - The power of anonymity

speaker: {name:'Roderick Lim Banda',webURLs:'[{url:'http://za.linkedin.com/in/rodericklimbanda',title:'Roderick on LinkedIn'},{url:'http://www.cioforum.co.za/home.htm',title:'CIO Forum'},{url:'https://twitter.com/rlimbanda',title:'Roderick on Twitter: @rimbanda'}]'}
description:
I am Roderick, an independent consultant in Enterprise Architecture and Software Architecture. I also co-founded a Chief Information Officer (CIO) Forum that is a social enterprise that has a strong partnership with the Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT).

We manage programmes and initiatives that include research collaborations, skills development, job creation and internships. We help to create work and job opportunities for unemployed youths particularly from poorer and disadvantaged communities. We focus on aspiring computing and IT professionals who need assistance in developing software programming skills and experience.

I TEDx because I believe that we all can make a difference in small but meaningful ways. As a collective, when we share and collaborate, greater things can happen. We can encourage and inspire one another and help discover both knowledge and humanity in the process.

My idea worth spreading to present at TEDxCapeTown 2012 is partly about the process of creating software factories in Africa. But it is more about the people that create software and how we can develop them within the unique context of the time and place in which we live. There is a perception that Africa cannot be competitive in the field of software development because of poverty and poor standards of education, particularly in maths and science. My story is about why I believe software programming can be a pathway to structured thinking and why it should be adopted as a compulsory subject in primary and secondary schools.
title: Roderick Lim Banda - African Software Factories

description:
I am Arthur, former book publisher, founder of Paperight and a Shuttleworth Foundation Fellow. For six years I've been working on ways to use technology to solve one problem -books are expensive and out of reach for most people, and that's wrong. At Paperight, we're looking to solve that problem.

I TEDx because when smart, thoughtful people share ideas well, the world gets an upgrade. And we need more upgrades.

 

My idea worth spreading to present at TEDxCapeTown 2012 is that if we can just get over being precious and controlling about it, the publishing industry can put every book within walking distance of every home within four years. And it'll hardly cost a thing.
title: Every book within walking distance of every home: Arthur Attwell

speaker: {name:'Marcela Guerrero Casas',webURLs:'[{url:'https://twitter.com/OpenStreetsCT',title:'Open Streets Cape Town on twitter: @openstreetsCT'},{url:'http://openstreetscapetown.blogspot.com/',title:'Open Streets Cape Town website'},{url:'http://www.bicyclecapetown.org/',title:'Bicycle Cape Town website'}]'}
description:
“Open Streets” celebrates the power of public space, free & safe mobility, and healthy communities. Modeled after Bogota’s Ciclovia, it consists of a temporary network of car-free areas and routes throughout the city.

Marcela Guerrero Casas is a Cape Town resident and an Open Streets activist. Born and raised in Bogota, Colombia, Marcela grew up riding bicycles around her hometown, Cota, and also on the famous Bogota-ciclovia (a weekly 100Km car-free cycle route around the city). Marcela studied in the United States and has lived in Southern Africa since 2006 working in the development sector. Marcela dreams of Open Streets in Cape Town where residents from all parts of the city congregate and take over the streets to build stronger communities and a more interactive city.
title: Dreaming of open streets: Marcela Guerrero Casas

speaker: {name:'Richard Palmer',webURLs:'[{url:'www.wspgroup.com',title:'WSP'},{url:'http://www.iol.co.za/dailynews/opinion/it-s-about-brave-decisions-1.1310907#.T9MM2uItg68',title:'Interview by Justin Nurse (LeadSA)'},{url:'http://thepointyend-of-sustainability.blogspot.com/2012/09/future-cities-africa-story.html',title:'Richard on future cities in his blog: the pointy end of sustainability'}]'}
description: Richard is an engineer by training, a consultant by profession and an ecologist at heart. In the real world he is employed by the WSP Group to offer design advice on green buildings and urban sustainability.
title: Adding vocabulary to the city's story: Richard Palmer

speaker: {name:'Blaq Pearl',webURLs:'[{url:'https://www.facebook.com/pages/Blaq-Pearl/116851515070880',title:'Blaq Pearl on Facebook: Blaq Pearl'},{url:'http://www.blaqpearl.co.za',title:'Blaq Pearl website'},{url:'https://twitter.com/blaqpearl_ZA',title:'Blaq Pearl on twitter: @blaqpearl_ZA'}]'}
description:
Talk title: Against All Odds
Janine's talk will be about her experience and challenges as an independent female artist, residing in Cape Town, and also a reflection on her travels abroad within this context.

Janine van Rooy, aka Blaq Pearl, is the only daughter, with two brothers, of Mr. and Mrs. Van Rooy. Born and raised in the working class community of Beacon Valley, Mitchell’s Plain, Cape Town. She is a gifted singer and writer who holds a degree in Psychology and Linguistics, as well as a social activist and youth development worker, who gets her inspiration from God, her parents, family, friends, neighbours and self. She is driven by a desire to tell her own story and the stories of others.

Janine / Blaq Pearl is also a Life Skills Facilitator and works with various organizations in different sectors that involves youth at risk, HIV/AIDS and women’s issues (in the communities, schools and prison). She transfers life skills using music and arts (poetry, creative writing & drawing) as methodology.

Janine started writing at the age of 12 to simply express herself and because she 'wanted to change the world'. Her first piece titled, ‘Life’s No Metaphor’ developed into a song. From that time already, she was doing choruses for her late brother ‘Devious’ (1977-2004), who is also her biggest musical influence.

Janine's aspirations include to contribute to positive change and empowerment, particularly in the music and youth sectors. To be a successful person with continuous growth and inspire upcoming artists & musicians
title: Against All Odds: Janine van Rooy, aka BlaqPearl

speaker: {name:'Trenton Birch',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.trentonandfreeradical.com',title:'www.trentonandfreeradical.com'},{url:'http://www.capetown.sae.edu',title:'SAE Institute South Africa'},{url:'https://twitter.com/freeradicallive',title:'Trenton on twitter: @freeradicallive'}]'}
description:
Trenton Birch (Trenton and Free Radical / Black Mango / SAE Institute):

Music and Cities

Music has and will always have a fascinating symbiotic relationship with modern culture. With an increase in urbanisation, cities are having a profound effect on how our culture evolves and this in turn is having a significant impact on how the music of our future is shaping itself.

Trenton Birch is an artist/DJ, record label owner, promotor and music / brand specialist who is recognized as one of the pioneers of the South African music industry. After several years in London he returned home and now heads up marketing for SAE Institute South Africa as well as lecturing the Music Business Curriculum, runs the event company Black Mango Music and fronts the band Trenton and Free Radical.

He was a radio and TV presenter and producer at the SABC (South African Broadcasting Corporation) for 5 years, a live producer for Real Concerts and Big Concerts and an artist manager.

Originally from Johannesburg, he moved to London where he worked for the world’s largest music promoter, Live Nation and was at the forefront of building music industry relationships with consumer brands while working at a number of high profile UK marketing agencies. He ran Carling's (the UK's biggest beer brand) live music account for two years and managed a number of large brand / music projects for Orange, Smirnoff, Reebok, Budweiser ......

He promoted South African music in the UK through his record label Black Mango Music who were responsible for the international release of Goldfish’s first album, developed the Breathe Sunshine series and started the African hip-hop website Afrolution. Trenton promoted Johnny Clegg in the UK for seven years and was responsible for the Amabala Music Festival - the largest SA music festival to take place in the UK feat - Springbok Nude Girls, Just Jinger, Henry Ate, Sugerdrive, Nagual and Barry Hilton. He has run music events around the world - including New York, Amsterdam, Ibiza and Malawi.
title: Music and Cities: Trenton and Free Radical

speaker: {name:'Jodi Allemeier',webURLs:'[{url:'http://www.linkedin.com/pub/jodi-allemeier/8/418/935',title:'Jodi on LinkedIn'},{url:'https://twitter.com/urbanjodi',title:'Jodi on twitter: @urbanjodi'},{url:'http://www.capetownpartnership.co.za',title:'Cape Town Partnership'}]'}
description:
Collaboration for a 24 hour city: designing social cohesion

Jodi is a Capetonian who holds qualifications and experience in the fields of social work, public and development management, economics and development finance. She joined Cape Town Partnership in 2012 as Central City Development Strategy Manager, where she works to build cross-sectoral and cross-disciplinary partnerships for a stronger city. She is inspired by the vision, creativity and collaboration displayed in the day-to-day lives of ordinary Capetonians. Prior to joining CTP, Jodi was a Director at Urban-Econ, a firm of development economists, where she gained experience working with multi-disciplinary teams on a range of social, economic, institutional, infrastructural and property development strategies and projects in and around Cape Town.
title: Collaboration for a 24 hour city: designing social cohesion: Jodi Allemeier

speaker: {name:'Jared Sacks & Nobanzi Dlodlo',webURLs:'[{url:'http://mg.co.za/article/2012-09-20-apolitical-truth-about-civil-disobedience',title:'Mail & Guardian article: Apolitical truth about civil disobedience'},{url:'http://mg.co.za/article/2011-10-28-why-are-some-occupiers-more-equal-than-others',title:'Mail & Guardian article: Why some occupiers are more equal than others'},{url:'http://rajpatel.org/2011/03/30/the-symphony-way/',title:'Raj Patel: the symphony way'},{url:'http://www.abahlali.org',title:'Abahlali baseMjondolo'}]'}
description:
Poor people are the experts on their own oppressive conditions

The philosophy behind TED talks posits that we need professionals; consultants and other experts have the answers to the worlds' problems. This talk, however, proposes that the key predicaments of modern society such as poverty, inequality and oppression, can only be solved by those who live every single day on the receiving end of this structural violence. Nobanzi and Jared believe strongly in the ability of people to collectively initiate and direct their own solutions rather than them relying on others for leadership and expertise. People are the experts of their own oppression and visitors can only begin to glimpse the possibilities of a new world if they are willing to listen to the words of the poor.

Jared Sacks was born in Johannesburg and went to university at UC-Berkeley. Since 2007, he has been living in Cape Town working directly with communities supporting their efforts to build authentic grassroots social change.
